Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Evaluating Models of Rehabilitation and Probation in the Criminal Justice System

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many communities in the United States increasingly have turned to alternative correction programs, such as probation and other forms of rehabilitation, to deal with high rates of incarceration. These various programs attempt to reduce prison costs and overcrowding, while better integrating offenders into society. This project will examine the utility of some rehabilitative programs as probation officers make decisions about high risk offenders. Consequently, the project will evaluate new case management tools in the criminal justice system with respect to decision making, recidivism, and public safety.

The project will examine various models of rehabilitation used during the probation phase of criminal justice. It does so by incorporating and integrating theories and models from the disciplines of rehabilitation, social psychology, and criminology. The result of the evaluation will be an integrated model of rehabilitation reform that provides high risk offenders and their probation officers with motivating goals to influence behavior and reduce recidivism. Evaluation will take place first through a field study of archival data from the Nebraska Office of Probation Administration, and then via an experimental design employing nearly 300 probation officers, in order to ascertain how probation officers use various rehabilitative tools and programs. Predictions of recidivism will be examined through the lens of various theories and models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research investigated methods to improve probationers’ motivation while also managing risk in the adult probation system by studying rehabilitation that aligns with the Regulatory Focus Theory of motivation (Crowe & Higgins, 1997; Higgins, 1998) measured through Goal Attainment Scaling (GAS; Kiresuk, Smith & Cardillo, 2014) and compared it to the Good Lives Model (GLM) (Ward, 2002) of offender rehabilitation. Both GAS and GLM , are closely aligned with the Risk-Need-Responsivity model (RNR) (Andrews, Zinger, Hoge, Bonta, Gendreau, & Cullen, 1990). The popular RNR model emerged from the changes the United States’ correction system has undergone in recent decades in response to the complaint that “nothing works” to reduce recidivism (Martinson, 1974).  The RNR utilizes valid and reliable risk assessment instruments and builds upon this risk principle with the need and responsivity principles (i.e., the need to take into consideration the individualized criminogenic risks and needs of offenders).  Critics of the RNR model argued that focusing on the risk factors alone ignores the offenders’ strengths (Wilson & Yates, 2009). In response, Ward (2002) developed the Good Lives Model (GLM), the main idea of which is to prepare offenders with resources necessary to lead a “good life” with meaningful life plans. GLM focuses on offender strengths and achieving 11 primary goods that people need to fulfill a good life (Ward, Yates, & Willis, 2012).

From a social psychological point of view, motivation features the process of self-regulation to promote healthy activities and avoid harmful ones (Carver & Scheier, 2012). Regulatory Focus Theory (RFT) (Higgins, 1998), posits that individuals will engage in one of two types of self-regulation, prevention or promotion. Prevention focuses on avoiding losses or negative outcomes while promotion focuses on attaining gains or accomplishing goals. RFT offers a social psychological model that could explain the nexus between the theory of the Good Lives Model and the motivating incentives intrinsic to Goal Attainment Scaling.

Goal Attainment Scaling (GAS) is a rehabilitation measurement and goal negotiation instrument that professionals use in a variety of areas ranging from physical to cognitive and emotional rehabilitation (Ward, 2012). The premise for the use of GAS in probation is that clients, in conjunction with supervising officers, select criteria for each goal that they strive to achieve and create scales to measure the extent of goal achievement. As such it is a measure of promotion self-regulation. Together, the officer and client reiterate the process: specifying goals, scaling goals, and evaluating goal achievement throughout the rehabilitation period documenting goal achievement in a quantitative manner until the client achieves all specified goals. In line with the GLM and Regulatory Focus, this method allows for the measurement of each individual’s progress or setbacks while working toward attaining meaningful goals that clients set with their probation officers. 

This study utilized archived data from 213 Nebraska who were high risk substance abusers undergoing specialized substance abuse supervision. The data included GAS goals, individual achieved goal scores, importance and difficulty ratings for the goals, baseline goal scores, overall achieved scores obtained at each session, index LS/CMI risk scores, outcome data for sanctions, violations, and revocations for offenders with high level misdemeanor or felony substance abuse charges. The central hypothesis was that GAS goals and the achievement of primary GLM goods would predict sanctions, violations, and revocations.  Furthermore, the more goals clients achieve the stronger is their promotion style regulation (i.e., emphasizing advancement through accomplishment of positive outcomes). Therefore, those with greater goal achievement would outperform those with fewer achieved goals, especially when the goals reflect primary or secondary GLM goods.

Two independent coders, blind to hypotheses, coded the negotiated GAS goals into one of the 11 primary goods in the GLM model with strong inter-agreement reliability (K = .95) to create a variable for each of the 11 primary goods in the GLM. Contrary to the main hypothesis, a series of multinomial logistic regressions found that the number of GLM goals was not a significant predictor of the probation success, substance violations, or sanctions. However, a second series of multinomial logistic regressions modeled the relationship between the established predictors (i.e. LSCMI risk scores and GAS scores) and successful completion of probation showed that the mean of the GAS accomplishment ratios, GAS minimum scores, and the LS/CMI risk score when predicting probation outcomes, χ2(10, N = 213) = 41.01 Nagelkerke R2 = .220,  p <.001. Furthermore the GAS parameters negatively predicted the number of subsequent violations, χ2(12, N = 213) = 36.39 Nagelkerke R2 = -.19,  p <.001).

In conclusion, although the GLM did not predict positive or negative outcomes for probationers, higher GAS achievement scores predicted fewer substance abuse violations as well as successful completion of probation. Our findings suggest that accomplishment of goals mutually negotiated between probation officers and clients can predict successful completion of probation beyond LS/CMI risk levels.
